div3.head: The st. Lawrence House.
div3.p: At the Southeast cor. Main & 9th Sts., Is for Rent for the unexpired lease of the present proprietor, and the Furniture, which is all new and of the most approved kind, is for sale on Accommodating terms.

The house contains Forty-Odd Rooms all well located and ventilated and is now supported by fifty good and reliable boarders, with a fair prospect of receiving a large share of Legislative patronage, as that body is now about to assemble, and several members have already engaged rooms at the St. Lawrence.
The proprietor is anxious to dispose of the Unexpired Lease, the Furniture, and the good will of the house, as he expects to engage in other business, and therefore invites a purchaser at private sale.
Apply on the premises.
de 3--1w

div3.head: Southern Savings Bank--
div3.p: Chartered by the Legislature.
whole joint Fund Pledged for Deposits.
Office--159 Main street, at the store of Watkins & Fieklen.
Officers.--P. T. Moore, President; W. A. Jenkins, Secretary; J. B. Watkins, Treasurer.--Directors — Wm. Ira Smith, J. F. Regnault. A. S. Samuel, Geo. I. Herring, J. H. F. Mayo, P. B. Price.

This institution, which has been in successful operation for several years, receives deposits of money in small or large sums, and pays the interest, (annually, if desired) at the rate of six per cent. per annum, it remaining on deposit 6 months, and 5 per cent. for shorter periods.
de 3--1m

div3.head:
A Book for the Times.
just published.
div3.p:
A Glance at States-rights — their misconstructions, their wrongs, and their rightful protections against the "Irrepressible Conflict." By a States-Rights Republican.
To which are added, the Bill of Rights of Virginia, and the Articles of Confederation.
Price $1.25.

p.q:
"The principles of the Bill of Rights are fundamental principles, subject to which, the State and Federal Constitutions were ratified.
They form, with other contemporary documents, the original and inalienable charter of State sovereignty, freedom and independence.
The Bill of Rights forms a vital part of the Constitution of the State; and they constitute, together, her Republican Government, every principle of which is guaranteed from Federal interference by the Federal Constitution."

div3.p: Copies mailed to any address., upon receipt of the advertised price.
de 6--3t(2dp) Publishers, Richmond, Va.

div3.head:
Armory Co. G, 1st Reg. Va. Vols.,
Richmond, December 6th, 1860.
div3.p: This Command will assemble at their Armory on this (Thursday) evening, at 6½ o'clock P. M., in full winter uniform, for the purpose of escorting the companies of the Regiment who will be present at the dedication of our new Armory.

The companies (or detachments,) are requested to march to the corner of 25th and Broad streets by 8 o'clock P. M., where we propose to meet them.
The Field and Staff Officers are all respectfully invited to be present.
Addresses may be expected on this occasion from General August, and other distinguished speakers.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. Gordon.
S. J. Tucker, 1st Sergeant.
P. S.--The citizens are invited to attend.
de 6--1t*

the performances will commence with

list.item: Spirit of the Hudson I. B. Phillips.

div3.p: Villagers, Spirits, Smugglers, &c., &c.

list.item: Dame Van Winkle Mrs. De Ber.

div3.p: Scenery and Incidents:

Act 1.--Period 1760.--The Village of Catskill.
The King's Birth-Day.
Merry-making.
The Country Schoolmaster and his Sweetheart.
The Course of True Love never did run smooth.
The Father and Son. Knavery versus Truth.
The Shrew.--
Rip Van Winkle,

The Father of the Village.
The Dutchman's View of Matrimonial Bliss.
The Temptation of Schnapps.
His Alluring Smile.
The Tempter Baffled.
The Triumph.
The reward of Resolution!
"Here's your good health.
Your family's good health.
And may you live long, and prosper."

Dutch Song and Chorus, by Rip and his Boon Companions.
"Look out, Boys, the Wild Cat's Coming." Rip and his Frau.
The Grey Mare is the Better Horse.
Dutch Waltz and Chorus, by the Villagers.
Comic Tableau!

Act 2.--Rip's Cottage.
Love in a Cupboard.
Old Rip at Home.
The Henpecked Husband. --Rip's Cunning to obtain the object of his attachment--"Schnapps." The Burgomaster.
A Wolf in Sheep's Clothing.
How to pay the Rent.
The Contract.
The Schoolmaster at his Old Tricks again.
Venus, the Tormentor of the Mentor — Knickerbocker and Crinoline.
Love's Disguises.
"Needs must, when the Devil Drives." Scene 2--
Old Rip!

The Sport.
The Meeting with the Spirit.
The Keg. "A friend in need is a friend indeed. "--Loud laughed the Spirit, as old Rip trudged on "I say, old chap, aren't you leading me astray." The Spirit of Hudson.
The Friendly Drink.
Old Rip overcome by his old enemy, Schnapps.
Triumph of the Spirit.
Defeat of Old Rip, and
the Sleep of twenty years.

Act 3.--Old Rip awakes after a refreshing sleep of twenty years--his first exclamation, "Don't throw that hot water on me!" Old Rip's Confusion.
Memory of the Past.
"I got pretty blue, dat's a fact." The Old Gun. The Bush.
His Astonishment.

Scene 2--Alice and Rowenna.
Love's Advice.
Arrival of Knickerbocker.
The Legislator, Good News.
Gustave Expected.
The Rival Claims.
Meeting of the Angry Lovers.
The Sailor and the Lawyer.
Knock-down Argument!

Scene 3.--The Town of Rip's nativity.
The Youthful Days of Liberty.
Old Rip's Return.
His Astonishment at the Changes
the Old Dutchman and the young
American!

No one knows Old Rip. Are we so soon forgotten.
Poor Rip's sorrow on hearing that his old frau is dead.
"So, the old woman is dead!
Well, she led me a hard life;
But after all she was mein frau, for all dat."
Old Rip's first Toast.
"And here's George Washington's good health — His family's — and may they all
Live long and prosper."

Scene 4.--The Trial--"Knavery versus Honesty. " Arrival of Rip. Knavery Defeated.
Old Rip Triumphant.
the Happy Union of the Lovers.

Glorious Termination to all Rip's Sorrows.
The Bright Prospect of the Coming Morrow.
"Here's your good health.
Your family's good health.
And may dey live long and prosper."
the performances will conclude with

div3.head: Watt's Cuff-Brace Ploughs.
div3.p: Geo. Watt & Co.--Established in 1846.

George Watt has obtained, at different times four separate patents on his Cuff-Brace Ploughs, acknowledged to embrace the most reliable improvements ever made on this implement, three of which patents have to run respectively ten, twelve and thirteen years, and has been awarded at the late Mechanics' Fair in Richmond a certificate of Silver Medal, for continued superiority in Ploughs, (the highest premiums given,) and at the last State Fair premium on the same, in addition to premiums awarded at all the preceding Fairs for years.

Within two months past he has added other valuable improvements, and we now invite all in want of Ploughs, warranted in every respect superior to others, to call and examine our large and varied stock of Ploughs, Castings and Agricultural Implements, and fresh and prime Garden and Field Seeds, &c., which we offer for sale on our usual accommodating terms.
George Watt & Co.,
One square below Exchange Hotel.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Male Professor of Music, to take charge of the Musical Department of the Wesleyan Female College, Murfreesboro', N. C., the 22d February next.
One who can teach the Modern Languages, as well as Music, would probably be preferred.
We should be pleased to receive applications from Professors of Modern Languages, as it is probable we shall need one the 22d February. Those applying will please state their place of birth, age, whether married or single, qualifications, religious faith, and salary.
Address "Rev. D. P. Wills." President Murfreesboro', N. C. de 3--ts

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--All persons to know that Prof. Adams and lady are still teaching the new and beautiful art of Oil Painting on Glass.
This work consists in Portrait and Landscape Sceneries.
This is a beautiful accomplishment for both ladies and gentlemen.
You can paint your own portrait that will look as natural as life, by learning this art; learnt in five lessons.
Terms, $10. This amount will cover the whole bill of learning this art perfectly.
Entire satisfaction given or no pay. Ladies taking lessons at my house will be taught by a lady, or I will give lessons at their own residence if desired.
Please call and examine specimens of our own and our pupils' work, at
Prof. Adams' office, on Mayo st.,

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--Having withdrawn from the house of Maddux & Co., I take this opportunity of returning my thanks to my friends who have patronized me, and also to state that I shall continue the Commission business in all its branches, and solicit the continued patronage of my friends and the public generally, assuring them that my best exertions will be used to give entire satisfaction to all those who may consign to me, and will, as heretofore, make sales as speedily as practicable, and remit proceeds at once.
I can be found, till 1st January, at Maddux & Co.'s office, Cary street, two doors below 13th. Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Book and Job Printing
div3.p:
The undersigned would respectfully announce to his customers and the public that he is now prepared to execute, at short notice, any description of Book and Job Printing, from the smallest visiting card to the largest law book.
He is also prepared to execute, in the neatest and most fastidious manner, all kinks of Fancy Printing, in various colors — Carmine, Pink, Purple, Bronze, Red, Brown, Yellow, Green — in short, any color that may be desired, and as many on a Job as any person may wish.
In this branch of his business, he defies competition by any printer in the city.
All he asks is a trial.
Satisfaction guaranteed.
George W. Gary,
Book and Job Printer.

div3.head: Notice to Tax Payers.
div3.p: --Pursuant an ordinance passed 11th January, 1853, attend at the Collector's Office, in the City Hall from the 15th to the 31st, December, inclusive, to receive the remaining half of taxes from such persons as are entitled to a deduction of 10 per cent by having previously paid the first half last, in accordance with said ordinance.
Julius A. Hobson. C. C. R.

N. B.--It will be seen from the above that the Collector is required to attend at the Office from the 15th to the 31st of the month, receive taxes remaining due from June last.
Before the term of the Hustings Court, he is required by the ordinance, to advertise delinquent sold for non-payment of taxes.
Persons who have not done so will see the necessity of and paying these taxes, as it will be impossible for the Collector to call on them before he advertises.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 18, Number 135, page 3.

div3.head:
[special Dispatch to the Richmond Dispatch.]
Senator Hale's speech — Determination of the Republicans--Hon, Roger A. Pryor — prospects gloomy, &c.
div3.p:
--Mr. Hale's speech in the Senate, this morning, is fatal to all movements for conciliation.
Disunion stock is rising.

Mr. Reagan reports nine-tenths of the people of Texas for secession.
The revolution in Houston does not call for a Convention.
The Hon. Mr. Sandrum says Louisiana is ripe for secession.

Mr. Bocock thinks the prospects for the Union are no brighter, and he will explain by letter, to-morrow, the secret growth of the Homestead bill, forced through the House this morning.
Also, Curtis' sixty millions Pacific Railroad bill, to be forced through next Monday.
Mr. Pryor is preparing a strong Southern speech.
The N. Y. Herald, of this morning, denies that Seward approves of Weed's course; but it is certainly known here that he was in favor of conciliation.
The N. Y. Tribune, of this morning, says: "The President's Message insults reason, outrages humanity, falsifies history, and defies common sense."N. Y. Tribune, It calls President Buchanan a liar.
The Southern members express their gratification at the uncompromising stand the Republicans have taken.
Secretaries Cass and Toncey are said to be in favor of a force bill against South Carolina.

div3.head:
Later from Europe.
Arrival of the Canadian.
div3.p: --The Canadian, from Liverpool on the 21st ult., has arrived.
The Asia, Borussia, Fulton, and Vigo, had arrived out.
The political news is unimportant.
The Prince of Wales had resumed his studies at Oxford.
There was considerable excitement in London on the 21st, by a report that the Emperor Napoleon had arrived quietly in England, and would reach the city that afternoon.
Commercial.

Liverpool, Nov. 22.--Cotton market opened very dull and declined , and even more on interior qualities.
On Thursday it improved in tone but did not advance-closed firm.
Breadstuffs quiet — buyers demand a reduction.
Inferior wheat slightly declined.
Provisions dull and steady.
Consols 93½@93.
Money sightly easier.
The Bank of England has agreed to exchange £2,000,000 of gold, for the same amount in silver, with the Bank of France.
A better feeling prevails everywhere.

div3.head: From the South.
div3.p: --The Georgia Methodist Conference, in session here, to-day appointed a committee to issue an address condemning the custom of the U. S. Navy requiring the use of the Episcopalian form of service on ships-of-war.
Charleston, S. C., Dec. 5. --The Courier and Mercury published the President's Message this morning, from advance copies.

Columbia, S. C., Dec. 5. --During a debate in the Legislature yesterday, on establishing an Ordnance Bureau, Mr. Rhett said he had bad for several years, in Charleston, eight of the largest sized Paixhan guns, which may be used in taking the forts at Charleston.

Mr. Marshall said the State had 382 companies of infantry, 50 companies of cavalry, 18 of artillery, and 2 companies of riflemen — making over 121 battalions, 56 regiments, 14 brigades, and 5 divisions.
Mr. McGowan said the total military force was about 65,000.
Milledgeville, Ga., Dec. 5. --There is nothing of interest.

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p: --Senate.--Mr. Slidell, of La., took his seat.
The Department reports were presented by the Vice President.
Mr. Powell, of Ky., gave notice that he should introduce a resolution referring the President's Message to a special committee.

Mr. Green, of Mo., offered a resolution instructing the Committee on Judiciary, to enquire into the expediency of establishing an armed police, between the free and slave States, for the better protection of property and more efficient execution of the fugitive slave law.

Mr. Lane, of Oregon, addressed the Senate.
He did not intend to make a speech, but desired to consider some of the questions now threatening the Union.
It was not merely who had been elected President, but that he had been elected on a platform upheld in direct conflict with the Constitution, and which denied the equality of the States.
If elected according to the letter of the Constitution, it was in opposition to the spirit; and if the question could be brought before the Supreme Court, he had no doubt Lincoln's election would be decided to be unconstitutional.
Messrs. Hale and others made some sneering remarks in reply to this assertion.
Mr. Lane proceeded to show that the nullification laws of the North must be repealed, and new guarantees given to preserve the Union.

Mr. Hale, of N. H, said there had been hopes that the President's Message would be one thing or another, out on carefully reading it, no one could tell what it did mean.--The first portion said that South Carolina had just cause to secede; the second, that she had no right to secede, and, third, that the United States had no right to prevent secession.
The President will not took the thing full in the face.
We must look to the ballot-box or else-where for a termination of the difficulties.
If Carolina does reject the ballot-box, and arms herself, we must look the danger straight in the face, and prepare for maintaining peace and putting down slavery.

Messrs. Iverson, of Ga., and Brown, of Miss., Indicated that their respective States would leave the Union before the 4th of March.
The former said that if the Republicans intended to use their power to put down slavery, the South intended to get out of the Union, and nothing under Heaven would prevent her going out peaceably, if she could — forcibly, if she must.
She was preparing to fight for her liberty, her rights, and her honor.
The enmity between the South and the North is deeper than hell, and separation is the only way in which they can live peaceably.
If war comes, we are willing to meet myriads of abolitionists.

Mr. Wigfall, of Texas, followed in behalf of the South, in an energetic strain.
He believed the President's Message would precipitate war, if the measures recommended in it were carried out.

Mr. Saulsbury, of Del., said his State was the first to adopt the Constitution, and would be the last to countenance anything tending to a separation of the States.
When the Union is destroyed by the madness of its two extremities, it will be time enough for Delaware to declare the course for her to pursue.
The foregoing debate was of a very exciting character.
Pending a motion to suspend the rule for the reference of the President's Message, the Senate adjourned, at 2½ o'clock.

House.--The House passed the Homestead bill by a majority of 56.
Some of the more Southern members declined to vote at all, and those who did, voted in the negative.
The Pension and Military Academy Appropriation bills were passed.
Various branches of the President's Message were referred to the appropriate standing committees.
Adjourned at 2 o'clock.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p: --In the Committee of Ways and Means, to-day, Mr. Phelps, of Mr. moved to issue $10,000,000 of Treasury notes to relieve the embarrassment of the Government.

Mr. Boteler's committee of one from each State, on the subject of the Secession part of the President's message, will not be appointed until Monday, as the Speaker wishes to consult the various delegations, with the view of obtaining the most conservative member of each.
[second Dispatch.]

Among the propositions under private discussion is one looking to the appointment of a delegation, by the conservative members in Congress from the slaveholding States, to proceed to the South Carolina Convention, with a view to a conference, and to appeal to that State to pause in her present movement.
The suggestion is made in intelligent circles that when the special committee on Boteler's resolution shall have been announced, the influential and conservative men from each State should communicate forthwith with the members of said committee, thereby thus contributing, to that extent, their power to fix upon some practicable mode for quieting the present political excitement.

Several schemes have already been discussed.
One of them is to make an effort to conciliate at least a large majority of the slaveholding and non-slaveholding States, whatever course the extreme States may pursue.

The Putnam phalanx arrived here this evening, and were received by the Washington Light Infantry.
In the course of the evening they were entertained by Secretary Toucey.

div3.head: Later from Mexico.
div3.p:
--The steamer Austin, from Brazon on the 1st, brings intelligence that a proclamation for a new Presidential election in Mexico has been issued, and that the favorite candidate for the Presidency is M. Lerdo de Tajeda.
In Northern Mexico the Liberals believed that the city of Mexico had been taken.

div3.head: Political.
div3.p: --A call, signed by Com. Stockton, Ex-Senator Thompson, Ex-Gov. Pierce and others, is issued, for a State Convention of Union men.

div3.head: The Electoral vote of New York.
div3.p: --The Electoral College of this State to-day cast its 35 electoral votes for Lincoln and Hamlin.

div3.head: Massachusetts Municipal elections.
div3.p: --E. A. Buffington, Republican, was re-elected Mayor to-day, with the entire Republican ticket for the City Council.
New Bedford, Dec. 3.--Issac C. Tober, citizen's candidate, was elected Mayor, with a large majority of the City Council on the same ticket.

Lawrence, Dec. 3.--Joseph R. Baker, Republican, was elected Mayor by 400 majority.
The City Council is Republican.

Springfield, Dec. 3.--The vote for Mayor to-day was a tie. Five Democratic and three Republican Aldermen were elected.
The Common Council stands--Republicans, 14; Democrats, 4.
Boston, Dec. 4.--James D. Green was reelected Mayor of Cambridge yesterday, by 16 plurality, over Mr. Sargent.
In Chelsea, Frank B. Fay was elected by 342 majority.

div3.head: Connecticut Municipal elections.
div3.p:
--At the town election to-day the Democrats carried the Board of Selectmen and a majority of the other town officers.
The average Democratic majority is thirty.
Norwalk, Dec. 3.--At our town election to-day the people's ticket, composed of Democrats and Republicans, was successful by a large majority.

div3.head: Fatal accidents at Newark.
div3.p: --Elizabeth Burns, the woman injured by the gun explosion on Saturday night which killed Murray, died of her injuries this morning.
A man named Miller was frozen to death on the meadows east of Newark on Saturday night.

div3.head: Railroad accident.
div3.p:
--Last evening, as a freight train was passing through the bridge at Freemansburg, eight cars ran off the track and broke through the flooring.
Francis Meighan, conductor, was killed.
The bridge was not injured.

div3.head: Old factory at Northboro' destroyed by Fire.
div3.p: --The old factory at Northboro' was destroyed by fire last night Loss $35,000. Many persons were thrown out of employment.

div3.head: Meeting of bankers.
div3.p:
--A meeting of the bankers and merchants has been held to adopt means for the relief of the money market.
The omission of special bills of credit was proposed.

div3.head: The vote of Texas.
div3.p: --Breckinridge's majority over Bell and Douglas is 32,109.

div3.head: Mayoralty Nomination.
div3.p: --Moses Kimball was last night nominated by the Republicans for Mayor of Boston.

div3.head: Northern Markets.
div3.p:
--Flour quiet and steady.
Wheat Steady — red $1.05@1.16.
Corn steady — new white and yellow 50@55.
Provisions dull at nominal rates.
Coffee quiet at 14@14½.
Whiskey lower — quoted at 18½.
New York, Dec. 5.--Stocks dull and lower-- N. Y. Central 74¼. Va. 6's 79; Mo, 6's 68

Regland & Co., we offer for sale the following valuable improved Real Estate, viz: Those two brick Tenements on the south side of Franklin, between 8th and 9th sts, occupied respectively by Messrs. J. B. Ficklin and Merriwether Jones, the former at $650 per annum, and the latter at $600 per annum.

Also, those three new and conveniently arranged brick Tenements on the south side of Franklin, between 3d and 4th streets. These tenements contain 19 rooms each (including servants' apartments,) and are supplied with gas and water, and furnished with cooking ranges, &c. One of them is now rented at $900 per annum, and the other two can be, as soon as they are ready for a tenant.
Also, three brick Stores and Dwellings on the north side of Cary, near 7th street, occupied by punctual tenants, at $280 per annum each.
Also, those seven brick Stores and Dwellings on the south side of Cary, near to 7th st., renting at from $300, $400 to $450 each.

Also, that most desirable brick Tenement at the corner of Grace and 1st streets, now or recently occupied by Robt. F. Morriss, at a rent of $700 per annum.
This is not only a very handsome tenement, but has every convenience that can be called for, including brick stable and carriage house.

As the owners are determined to sell, persons disposed to purchase any of the foregoing Real Estate, are requested to make early application, and for cash, or short negotiable paper, (interest added,) a bargain will be given.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p: --Ran away on Saturday, the 3d inst, from the employment of Dr. John B. Eastham, of Louisa county, a Negroman, named Ralph, belonging to the estate of Jesse Perkins, dec'd.

Ralph is about twenty-two years of age, black, about five feet five inches high one of his front teeth is our, and the rest are very broad and white.
No peculiar mark about him is remembered, but we think he has a scar between his forefinger and thumb on one of his hands — can't say which.
He, it is said, can write a good hand, and is probably making his way to a free State.--The above reward will be paid for his apprehension in the State and delivery to us or being placed in a jail so that we get him; or, if taken out of the State and delivered to us, or placed in a jail in this State, so that we get him, a reward of $100 will be paid.
Wm. Crawford,
John R. Quarles,
Frank T. West,
Ex'ors of Jesse Perkins, dec'd.
Trevillian's Depot, Louisa co.,
Nov. 12th 1860. no 14--ts

div3.head: Seventy-Five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $75.00 for the apprehension of my Negrogirl, Peggy, who absconded about three weeks ago. She is a low, thick set mulatto, with short curly hair, and is about sixteen years old. Her dress cannot be described, as she has been seen several times in this city since she left, and had on a different dress each time.
E. L. Chinn.

div3.head: Artificial Teeth.
div3.p:
--the Cheoplastic and Vulcanite Process.--G. W. Jones, Dentist, having the right for the above mode of making Teeth and being satisfied of its absolute superiority over all other methods, can with confidence commend it to those desiring full or partial sets of teeth, and especially such as may be dissatisfied with those they are now using.
The perfect adaptation of the plate to the mouth, and the suction thereby secured, enables him to insert one or more teeth without clasps. This method having been adopted by those standing highest in the profession, North and South, testimonials will be given and specimens exhibited to those wishing to see them.
Sets of Teeth, on gold or any other plate, will, of course, be made for those preferring them Filling, Cleansing, Extracting, and all other operations gently and thoroughly performed.
Teeth extracted by Electricity, without pain.

Binford, John Whitlock's estate and others, and supposed to contain about 85 acres.

the purchaser executing his bond for the deferred payments, and title retained until ordered by Court.
de 6--tds Geo. D. Pleasants, Com'r.

div3.head: Administrator's sale of Personal property, at Auction.
div3.p: --On Monday, the 17th day of December, (immediately after the sale of the land,) I shall proceed to sell to the highest bidder, all of the Personal Estate of John J. Eppes, dec'd, consisting of Horses, Cows, crop of Corn, Fodder, Shucks, Household and Kitchen Furniture, &c.
Terms.--All sums under $20, cash; that amount and over, 6 months credit will be given, the purchaser executing bonds, with good security.
All persons having claims against the estate of John J. Eppes, dec'd, will please present them to me and those who are indebted to the said estate will please make prompt payment to me.
Geo. D. Pleasants,

de 6--tds.

div3.head: The Singer Sewing Machines.
div3.p:
--The marked and ever extended popularity of Singer's Sewing Machines, both in America and Europe, is such as best to establish their superiority over all others in the market.
Sewing Machines, so called, may be bought, it is true, for a smaller amount of dollars, but it is mistaken economy to invest anything in a worthless or unreliable article, and those who will do so must abide the consequences.
Singer's New Family Machines
In order to place the very best Family Machines in the world within the reach of all, we have reduced our Letter A, or transverse Shuttle Machines, beautifully ornamented, to Fifty Dollars.
Singer's No. 1 and 2 Standard Shuttle Machines,

Both of very general application and capacity, and popular both in the family and the manufactory.
Prices reduced respectively from $135 and $150 to $90 and $100.
Singer's No. 3 Standard Shuttle Machine,

For carriage-makers and heavy leather work.
Price, complete, $125.

Also, to complete the list, an entirely new article, unequaled for manufacturing purposes, noiseless, rapid, and capable of any kind of work.
Price, including iron stand and drawers, $110, cheaper at that, in view of its value, than the machines of any other maker as a gift.

All of Singer's Machines make the interlocked stitch with two threads, which is the best stitch known.
Every person desiring to procure full and reliable information about Sewing Machines, their sizes, prices, working capacities, and the best method of purchasing, can obtain it by sending for a copy of "I. M. Singer & Co.'s Gazette," which is a beautiful pictorial paper, entirely devoted to the subject.
It will be supplied gratis.

Needles, Thread, Cottons, Silk, and all necessary articles used with Sewing Machines, kept constantly on hand for sale.
Also, a practical machinist, who is ever ready to attend on our customers, if required.

Messrs. Singer & Co.'S office being conducted on the most thorough business principles, by an entirely new set of hands, we feel confident of doing our share of the business, as we have always done heretofore.
I. M. Singer & Co.,
240 Main street, Richmond.

div3.p:
Commissioners' sale of Real Estate in the Town of Fulton, near to Rocketts.--As Commissioners of the Circuit Court of Henrico, appointed by a decree entered on the 1st November, 1860, in the case of Euroughty and wife against Bergman, &c., we shall sell at public auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 10th December, 1860, at 3½ o'clock P. M., (if fair; if not, the first fair day.) the real estate located as above, of which the late Fred. Bergman died seized, and now occupied by his widow.
There are several beautiful building lots, and an excellent new Brick Tenement, used as a Store and Dwelling, and considered an excellent stand for business.

Terms.--Enough in cash to defray the expenses of sale and costs of suit; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, satisfactorily endorsed, and title retained till the further order of the Court.

Bunt, to secure a debt of $350, with interest, I shall proceed to sell, on the premises, on Tuesday, 11th December, 1860, at 4 o'clock P. M., that Land, with a Building thereon, lying on the south side of Duval street, nearly opposite the Duval street Church and fronting 21 feet on said Duval street. The lot is part of No. 11, in Duval & Pleasants Plan.

Terms.--Cash to satisfy expenses of sale and debt secured by trust deed; for the balance, on a credit of six months, purchaser executing his negotiable note, interest added, and title retained until credit instalment is paid.
John A. Hutcheson,
Sheriff of Henrico county, and as such Administrator of Richard J. Blunt.

Two most valuable Building Lots.
On the east side of 3d, between Franklin and Main streets. For sale at Auction.

M., a portion of that very valuable Lot, located as above, now in the occupancy of Rev. Dr, Minnigerode viz: A Lot fronting 45 feet on the east side of 3d street, north of the dwelling, running back 90 feet; also, a Lot fronting 60 feet on the east side of 3d street, south side of the dwelling, running back on the north side of Main street 90 feet to the residence of Dr. F. W. Hancock.
This is justly regarded as very valuable real estate; being not only in a most delightful neighborhood, but quite convenient to the business parts of the city.

consisting of a Lot of Ground, fronting 33 feet on the north side of Clay street. between 2d and 3d running back at right angles about 150 feet, to an alley 13 feet wide, with the large and handsome Brick Dwelling House, and all other improvements to said lot belonging, it being the late residence of the said Richard Walsh.

div3.p:
valuable Market Farm, Five miles below Richmond, on the Charles city Road, containing 45 Acres, for sale at public Auction.--At the request of Mr. Theodore Hoppe, I shall sell at public auction on the 10th day of December, at the hour of 11 o'clock, upon the premises (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter.) that valuable small Farm situated as described above, containing 45 acres, and adjoins the lands of Ro. Farrar and others; about half cleared; the balance woods.
The cleared land is well adapted to the growth of the usual crops, especially vegetables.--The improvements are sufficient for the accommodation of a moderate sized family.
There is a pump of excellent water in the yard.
The location is healthy and society good.
Immediately after the sale of the farm, will be sold all the Stock, Plantation Utensils, crop of Corn Fodder, &c.
Mr. H.Ppe, living on the premises, will take pleasure in showing it to any one wishing to purchase.
Terms--Made known on day of sale;
no 28--dtds Ho. B. Lyne, Auct.

div3.head:
Executor's sale of a valuable Farm in Henrico County, 12 miles below the city of Richmond, on the New Charles city Road, containing about 500 Acres of Land, together with the stock of Horses, (several of which are young and very valuable) Cows House Plantation Utensils.
Crops of Corn Shucks, Fodder, Straw, &c., at Auction.
div3.p:
--I will as the Executor of John Brackett, deceased, sell on Tuesday, the 18th of December, 1860, at his late residence, at the hour of 11 o'clock, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) that valuable Farm upon which the said Brackett resided at the time of his death, situated as described above, containing about 500 acres of land, half cleared, a portion of which is meadow, very rich and productive. --The balance of the land is well set in pine and oak. The improvements consist of a framed dwelling, containing 7 or 8 rooms; kitchen, negro quarters, barn, stable, carriage- house, &c. The location is considered very healthy and society good, convenient to churches and mills.
And immediately after the sale of the Farm, will be sold the stock of Horses, Cows, Hors, Plantation Utensils a Carriage and Harness, (nearly new,) House-hold and Kitchen Furniture, crops of Corn, Shucks, Fodder, Straw, &c.

Terms of Sale.--For the land, one-third cash; balance upon a credit of one, two and three years, to bear interest from day of sale, which is to be paid semi-annually.
For personal property, all sums of twenty dollars and under, cash; sums over twenty dollars, six months credit, for approved paper, to be given before property is delivered.
William Brackett.
Ex'or of John Brackett, deceased.

div3.head:
Richmond Type Foundry,
located in the law Building,
on Franklin street.
div3.p:
The proprietors of the above establishment beg leave to say that they are prepared to execute any orders for Newspaper, Book or Job Printing Offices, and are now manufacturing, on the spot, a new dress for the Richmond Dispatch.
In soliciting the patronage of the South we guarantee to furnish as good an article as can be had North, and at New York prices.
We have extensive business connections with nearly all the type foundries in the United States, and are, therefore, enabled to furnish Type of other manufacturers when required.

We desire every newspaper in the South to copy this advertisement for one month sending us on copy of the paper, and they will receive their pay by purchasing of us five times the amount of their bill for such advertisement.
Walker & Pelouze.

div3.p: --to the Creditors of Daniel Hagerty and of Hagerty & Starke.--Daniel Hagerty having assumed, by contract, the payment of the debts of the late firm of Hagerty & Starke, and being entitled, under the same contract, to all the assets of the late concern, including debts due it, and said Hagerty having, by deed dated the 21st November, 1860, recorded on the same day in the Clerk's Office of the Hastings Court for the city of Richmond, conveyed his stock of goods, and all his property and asses of every description, real and personal, to the undersigned, in trust, for the benefit of his creditors and the creditors of Hagerty & Starke, according to certain classes therein arranged; and said deed also providing, among other things, that no creditor shall be entitled to any benefit therefrom unless he assents to the terms of the said deed by signing the same within thirty days from its date--

Notice is hereby given to all persons indebted to the said Hagerty, or to the said firm, to settle immediately with the undersigned, and to persons having claims under the terms of said deed, to present the same.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 18, Number 135, page 4.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
affairs in the country.
div3.p:
We had quite a considerable fall of snow in this region last night.
When I awoke this morning, the ground looked as though it had been freshly sown with salt, (mind, I do not say sown with fresh salt,) or powdered white sugar.
I apprehended a severe spell and a freeze upon the back of it. But the clerk of the weather seems to have been satisfied with giving us a specimen of what he can do when the fancy takes him, and has let us off with a very moderate proof of his ability.
At present the sun is shining in unclouded glory, and not a vestige remains of the last night's sprinkle.
The air is soft and balmy, and the day would do no discredit to the prescriptive beauty of May.
I recollect that on this day twelve months ago, the Howitzers (who, by-the-bye, wore the red shirt before Garibaldi thought of adopting it, and from whom, no doubt, instead of the firemen, he borrowed the idea,) broke up from their encampment in Charlestown.
I recollect — and shall always recollect — with great distinctness, the events of that day, which restored us war-worn veterans to the peace and comfort of our own firesides.
Never shall I forget the long muskets and the long bayonets that we bore with us on our triumphant return.
Indeed, I may say that my memory on that subject is a memory of feeling.
We had occasion to fire but once, and then it was at a hill-side, not at an enemy.
I have no doubt if an enemy had been before us, our guns would have hurt him badly; at least, if they did not, they would have let him off more easily than they did a great many of us. But alas!
for war and glory! "Othello's occupation's gone." I have nothing more to relate of
--"Hairbreadth'scapes
And moving accidents by flood and field."
Therefore, since your readers delight in things which smack of gunpowder, let me return to war's first cousin, hunting.

It seems that your report of the abundance of game throughout the country, or some other cause equally moving, started off more than one Nimrod to the country.
Several of these are now staying at the house of a gentleman within sight of the spot where I now sit.--They took the field in great force yesterday morning, in company with a young gentleman of the medical profession, who professes likewise to be no small adept at bringing down game in full career.
I have not learned what success they met with, but I heard one most awful big gun!
They must have been shooting at an elephant!
So much powder could not have been burnt upon a beast of less imposing magnitude.
I expect to hear great tidings before the day is out. I mean to come in, if possible, for a part of the ivory.
One of these gentlemen Nimrods is a particular friend of mine, who holds an office in the State Library.
It is very seldom that he takes the field, I believe, and, no doubt, he meant that big gun for a holiday salvo, for I suspect it was he that fired it. I am dying of curiosity to know what he shot.
Two of the others were relatives of his, and have the reputation of being considerable marksmen.
I wish them plenty of game, good dogs, guns that never miss fire, and an unerring aim. Whether any of this good fortune befall them, or whether they miss of it all, we should think that an excursion of the kind, after long attention to business, must be a most delightful recreation to a man who is fond of a dog and a gun.

The snow this morning cut short a projected fox chase, in which two young ladies were expected to join.
Is it not a pity that such recreations are not pursued more steadily by our young country women ? Nothing is more invigorating, or more exhilarating, than active exercise on horseback.
Nor is there a more graceful accomplishment, in the long catalogue of things that much become a woman, than perfect horsemanship.
Of course, it is not expected that a young lady should leap a ditch, or clear a fence, like a veteran fox hunter.
Indeed, there is very little of that sort of exercise required, even of the most expert horseman.
But the excitement of the chase, the galloping motion of the horses, the cry of the hounds, the shouts of the hunters, are all calculated to make the blood circulate rapidly, to bring health to the frame, bloom to the cheeks, and brightness to the eye. It is not at all necessary, I apprehend, that exercise of this kind should be associated with a masculine character, or with the least want of refinement.
On the contrary, it is healthful, innocent, and full of grace.
It is especially suited to the young, and youth is so decidedly the season of enjoyment that those who do not enjoy themselves in youth will be apt to pass through life without enjoying themselves at all.

There have been three revolutions in foxes, and the dogs that chase them, within my recollection.
When I first remember there were none but grey foxes in all these parts.
They are much smaller, much weaker, and much shorter of wind than the red foxes.
The hounds that were used for chasing them were slow-footed animals, very sure upon the trail, with most sonorous throats.
Some of them had voices like the sound of the great bell at Moscow, or rather like what I suppose it must have been — others like the bell at the barracks — others like the little silver bells that you keep on the table.
Altogether, the chime was delightful when the cry was up and the chase in view.
For hours would they toil after the game, making the woods re-echo to their music.
The hounds of Theseus, as described by Shakespeare, who was himself a keen sportsman, must have been like these:
"Now in pursuit, but matched in mouths like bells,
Each under each; a cry more tunable
Was never hallowed to or cheered with horn,
In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly."

In the course of time a revolution took place among the Northern hordes of foxes.--The red foxes, like the Scythians of the olden time, or the hordes that overran the Roman empire in the Middle Ages, were driven from their habitations by superior power, and they came down upon the South.
The grey fox quickly disappeared, and the red fox usurped his patrimony.
With the grey fox disappeared the slow, deep-toned, loud-mouthed hound, and a new race, very swift in pursuit, but entirely wanting the musical gifts of their predecessors, came into vogue.
Very different was the red fox, from the rival whom he had dispossessed.
It was extremely difficult to catch; indeed, we believe he was seldom ever caught upon the ground.
Late in the season, about February or the early part of March, he would run a pack of hounds all day. In our boyhood, we well remember an old stager, who had a white tip on the end of his tail, and was thence called silver tail.
This fox became so well known, that the hunters would call off their dogs when they found they were in pursuit of him. He knew the sound of the horn as well as the hunter did, and as soon as he heard the latter blowing up his dogs preparatory to a start for home, he was up and off over the hills, like a streak of lightning.
He never could be taken napping.
It was said that on one occasion, he led a pack of hounds from a point about half a mile above the present residence of Dr. Reynolds Trent, to Bolling's Island, a distance of at least fifteen miles as the crow flies, and that he camped at night within a few hundred yards of the spot whence he started in the morning.
On that famous day, he broke down every horse, and threw every dog out of the chase.
Several hunters, at different times, reported that they had captured old "silver tail," but he was like John Barleycorn, up again as soon as the next pack came along.--The hunters were deceived.
There were other Richmonds in the field.
They took, no doubt, foxes with tips on the ends of their tails, but not the genuine Simon Pure.
He, we doubt not, died at a good old age, with all his children and grandchildren — at least all the hunters had spared — gathered around him, and mourning their irreparable loss. P.

div3.head: Infirmary of the Medical College.
div3.p: --This Institution, situated at the corner of Marshall and College streets, is fully provided for the accommodation of both White Persons and Negroes, requiring medical treatment.
White Persons who desire it, can be furnished with private Rooms, where they will enjoy every comfort and convenience.

The accommodations for Slaves, as heretofore, are ample, and the attention of owners of negroes, both in the city and country, is again invited to the great advantages afforded by the Infirmary for the Medical and Surgical treatment of this class of patients.
Lying-in Women are also received and carefully attended to.

All patients are under the care of the Professors of the College, who visit the wards daily, aided by an efficient corps of assistants.
In cases of difficulty, a consultation of the Professors is held, without extra charge to the patient.

The charges for Medical Attendance.
Board, Nursing and Medicine are as follows:
For less than a week, (except in private rooms,) $1 per day — provided that the aggregate shall not exceed the charge for a full week.

For Surgical Operations, by agreement with the proprietors of the Bellevue Hospital, a small extra charge will be made, varying from $2 to $30, according to the difficulty and importance of the operation.
All charges payable on the removal of the patient.
no case of small Pox, or any other infectious disease, nor any case of Insanity, will be admitted.
Attending Physicians--Profs. Tucker Conway and McCAW.
Attending Surgeons--Profs. Gibson, Peticolas and Wellford.
Resident Physician--Dr. Thos. L. Hunter.
Steward — F. M. Parrish.
President--Dr. L. S. Joynes.
Persons in the country, desirous of sending patients to the Infirmary, may address the President, Steward, or any of the Professors of the College.

div3.head: Main street Hospital for Slaves.
div3.p:
--This Hospital is situated near the corner of Main and 26th streets, and is admirably adapted in airiness, privacy and healthfulness of position, to the purposes for which it has been instituted, namely: For Medical, Surgical and Obstetrical treatment of Slaves.--The rules and regulations governing this institution have already been published.
A circular containing full particulars will be furnished those who may desire further information.

Terms.--Patients per week, $5 less than a week, $1 per diem; but the aggregate shall not exceed the charge for a full week. Patients attending the daily examinations (not fit subjects for Hospital Confinement.) charged the regular fee adopted by the profession at large.--The above charges include board, medicine, medical attendance and nursing.
Surgical operations charged according to rules of other Hospitals of the city.
For further information, apply to the Physician resident at the Hospital, or to either of the undersigned Pphysicians and Proprietors.
Frs. W. Hancock, M. D,

Main st., bet. 3d and 4th.
or No. 130 Main st.
st. Geo. Peachy, M. D.,
Exchange Hotel, or Grace st., bet. 5th and 6th.

Near Ballard House, or cor. Main and 7th sts.
Philip S. Hancock, M. D.,

div3.head: Bellevue Hospital.
div3.p: --This institution, which has been in successful operation seven years, is situated on Church Hill, Richmond, Virginia, in a delightful, airy position, and is furnished with every convenience conducive to the comfort of patients and the successful treatment of medical and surgical diseases.
Rooms have been nicely furnished, suitable to the accommodation of gentlemen who may find it inconvenient to be treated at their private lodgings.
Particular attention will be paid to the lying-inwards, which are very commodious.

Having been heretofore liberally patronized by owners of slaves, both in the city and country, we can, with increased confidence, call their attentention to the great advantages afforded by our "Hospital," for the medical and surgical treatment of Slaves, and promise to spare no pains to furnish them proper accommodations and every necessary attention.

table.head:
Terms:
(payable on the removal of the Patient.)

row.cell: White Patients, in Private Rooms, per week

div3.p: (For fractions of a week, after the first week, at the same rates, i. e. 71 cents per day.)
For less than a week, (except in private rooms,) $1 per day, provided that the aggregate shall not exceed the charge for a full week.

This includes all charges for Board, Medical Attendance, Nursing and Medicine.
By an arrangement with the Infirmary of the Medical College, a small additional fee, ranging from $2 to $30, will be charged for Surgical cases.
The particular sum may be ascertained before-hand by application to one of the attending Physicians.
No Small-Pox admitted.

All patients are under our immediate care, one of us visiting the wards once a day, and oftener when necessary; and in cases of difficulty, a consultation of all the physicins is held, without extra charge to the patient.
A resident Physician, two Students and a Matron, have the patients under their immediate supervision, and personally administer all medicines ordered.
When requested, weekly reports will be given of the condition of patients.
Persons in the country, wishing to send patients to our Hospital, may address either of the Physicians, or the Resident Physician.

When desired, we will send a comfortable covered vehicle to any part of the city for patients. --For this purpose, a message left at the Hospital, or a Mr. Thos. Pemberton's, on Main, between 17th and 18th streets, will be attended to.
James Bolton, M. D., Grace st., between 4th and 5th.
Thomas Pollard, M. D., Governor st., 1st door above Richmond House.
O. A. Crenshaw, M. D., opposite American Hotel.
Wm. W. Parker, M. D., Law Building, corner of 12th and Franklin sts.
C. M. Hunter, M. D., Resident Physician.
Mrs. W. E. Perkins, Matron ja 2--1y

the Wedding Ring is emblematic of the marriage relation.
Gold will wear out by friction, abrasion, &c.; but never rusts — never tarnishes — is always bright.
Thus, with life, the Ring is without end; so likewise is the union without interruption or end, except by the death of the parties.

The Wedding Ring being plain, shows that the fair one to whom it is given is, in the estimation of the giver, the most perfect and loveable of her sex, needing not the foreign aid of ornament to render her just the woman for him to love and cherish all his days.

A good assortment of plain Gold Rings, suitable for Wedding Rings, just finished, can be found at 96 Main street, where will be found Watches, Jewelry, Silver Ware, Silver-plated Ware, Spectacles, &c., &c. Watches, Jewelry and Spectacles repaired in the best manner.

I am now located five doors above my old stand, next door to C. W. Purcell & Co.'s Brokers' Office, and near Governor, on Main street, No. 126, where I would be pleased to meet my old customers, and the customers generally.
Those in the habit of giving me their orders for Fall Clothing, will do me a favor to wait until I can call on them, or leave word at my store when to call on them, and all orders in my line will be as promptly attended to as heretofore, I have not, and don't intend to, discontinue business for any such cause.
Call and see me, at 126 Main street. [au 23--ts] Wm. Ira Smith.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--We very earnestly request customers and others, who have our Bags, to send them to us full of grain, if ready to send it, or empty, by the next train.
We are suffering great inconvenience for want of our Bags that are idle in various hands who have neglected to return them.
In a short time we must make up bag accounts and charge the holders with them.
When we send bags to any person, they should be returned promptly.

Much of the wheat we receive is damp.
Farmers ought to dry it at home.
Barns, granaries and "all out of doors" are big enough to spread it in. Farmers lose immensely by inattention to this point.

We have fallen on perilous times, when debt is fearful.
Filling orders for guano, &c., on the faith of growing crops, won't do for those who have to buy them on time.
A safe principle of individual economy is to make money before we spend it.

div3.p:
--New Arrangement.--important to Travelers.--through Tickets and through Checks.--great Northern Route — Carrying the great United States Mail.
Twice daily (Sunday night excepted) between Richmond, Alexandria, Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York, and all important points West, via Acquia Creek and Washington, over the Richmond, Fredericksburg & Potomac Railroad, to the Potomac river, 75 miles, and by splendid and comfortable steamers thence to Washington, 55 miles, in all 130 miles in seven hours; being a comfortable and perfectly safe rate of speed.
Hours of departure: 5:30, A. M., and 7 P. M.
Baggage, under charge of Special Agents, Checked through to Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York.

Through Tickets can be secured to the following points — viz: Baltimore, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, Columbus, Indianapolis, Cairo, Dayton, Jeffersonville, Rock Island, Zanesville, Washington New York, St. Louis, Chicago, Pittsburg, Louisville, Decatur, Newark and Vincennes.
Passengers breakfast and sup at Ashland and dine on board the comfortable steamer between Acquia Creek and Washington.

Persons wishing to obtain tickets for servants for Washington city and points further North, must, in all cases, be vouched for by some responsible white citizen of Richmond, is person, known to the officers of the Road, as Tickets will be sold if applied for by letter.
For further information, apply at this office Broad street, Shockoe Hill.
Jas. B. Winston, Gen'l Ticket Ag't.

div3.head: Virginia Central Railroad.--Fall Arrangement.
div3.p: --On and after Monday, the 1st of October, the Mail and Passenger Train will leave Richmond daily, (except Sunday,) at 6.30 A. M., for Staunton and all intermediate way stations, connecting at Gordonsville with the Orange and Alexandria Railroad Trains for Alexandria and intermediate stations, and at Charlottesville with their trains for Lynchburg and all points West and South-west of that place; and every other day, viz: Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, for Jackson's River and stations West of Staunton.
Harman & Brown's Stages connect with the train at Staunton on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, and at Goshen on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, for Lexington.

Harman, Mason & Co.'s Stages connect with the train on Tuesdays. Thursdays and Saturdays, at Millboro', for the Warm Springs, and at Jackson's River, for the White Sulphur Springs, Lewisburg, &c. Returning, the Mail Train leaves Jackson's River on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, at 3.15 P. M. for Staunton.

A Freight Train, with a passenger car attached, will leave Waynesboro', at 7.45, and Staunton at 9.45 A. M., on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays for Jackson's River.
Returning, leave Jackson's River on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays at 7.45 A. M., for Waynesboro'.

Through tickets for the Warm and White Sulphur Springs, Lexington, Lewisburg, &c., also, for Winchester, Lynchburg, Bonsack's. Salem, Shawsville, Christiansburg, Bristol, Knoxville.
Dalton, Chattanooga, Nashville, Grand Junction, Memphis, Canton, New Orleans and all important points in the Southwest, can be procured at the ticket office.
oc 1--ts Thos. Dodamead, Gen'l Supt.

div3.head: Richmond and Danville Railroad--Express Freight and Accommodation Trains.
div3.p: --On and after Monday, Oct. 1st, an Express, Freight and Accommodation Train will leave Richmond daily (Sundays excepted,) for Lynchburg and intermediate points, leaving Richmond at 4 P. M., and arriving in Lynchburg at 3 A. M., in time to connect with the passenger train going west on the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad.
Returning, leave Lynchburg at 7.25 P. M., immediately on the arrival of the train from the west, and arrive in Richmond at 6.10 A. M.
se 29--ts C. G. Talcott, Supt.

div3.head: Travelers to the North.--1860.
div3.p:
Northern Central Railway.--Trains leave Calvert Station, Baltimore, daily, (except Sunday,) at 8.30 A. M., and at 5.30 P. M., for Niagara Falls, (fare only ten dollars,) Buffalo, Owego, Oswego, Toronto, Hamilton, all parts of Western New York and Canada, for Detroit, Chicago, Cincinnati, St. Louis, and all parts of the West.
Northwest and Southwest.
Travelers can go to Detroit, Chicago, Milwaukee, &c., via Niagara Falls, at the same cost as by any other route.

A new route to New York is now open by this Road, via Harrisburg and Jersey City, with only one change of cars.
Fare $6. Take the 8.30 A. M. train and go through by daylight, over first-class Roads and through a beautiful country.
Try it.
Buy tickets only to Baltimore.
Jas. C. Clarke, Sup't.
John T. Rigney, Assistant Sup't. je 13--1y
Cox's line.--Freight Boats to Lynchburg three Times a week--Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.

Boat Bristol, Capt. Chas. J. Johnson.
Boat J. J. Irby, Capt. Wm. F. Cleveland.
Boat Fame, Capt. Wm. H. Parsons.
Boat Olivia, Capt. J. J. Peters.

div3.p:
These Boats are all of the first class, commanded by careful and experienced Captains, and leave promptly as advertised.
The subscriber thankful for past favors, begs a continuance of the same.
Wm. P. Cox, Agent,
At the Shed, Dock st., in rear of old Gas Works.

div3.head: Notice to the public!
div3.p: --New and important Arrangement, 1860.--The Adams Express Company respectfully announce to the public that they have arranged to run their Express Twice Daily from New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore to Richmond, thereby affording unusual facilities for obtaining their freight and packages in the shortest possible time.

Expresses leave New York at 1.5 and 6 o'clock P. M. Expresses leave Philadelphia at 8 A. M. and 11 P. M. Expresses leave Baltimore at 4.20 A. M. and 4.20 P. M., arriving in Richmond at 3.10 A. M. and 2 P. M.
Expresses leave Richmond for New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore, and all points North and West, at 6.30 A. M. and 6.30 P. M.
Freight and packages should in all cases be at our office one hour before the departure of the Trains.
Expresses for the South leave Richmond Twice Daily, at 4.30 A. M. and 2.45 P. M.

The Adams Express Company feel that they can guarantee to the public civility, attention and satisfaction in all their intercourse with their officers in Richmond, and nothing will be left undone on their part to meet the wants of their customers.

Freight and packages arriving by the Express from the North at 3 o'clock P. M. will be delivered immediately, thereby giving to our customers an advance of twelve hours over our arrangements heretofore.

Steamer Expresses, to and from New York, Semi-Weekly.
Freights delivered immediately upon the arrival of the ship.
heavy and Light Freights Packages, Money, Bonds, Legal Documents, &c., forwarded with safety and dispatch to all parts of the United States, Canada and Europe.
notes, Drafts and Bills, with or without Goods collected at all accessible points throughout the United States, and prompt returns guaranteed.
Slaves forwarded by each of our Expresses, in charge of careful and reliable messengers.
Tobacco and other samples carried at unusual low rates.
All freights promptly called for and delivered without extra charge.
For further information, please call at our office, 202 Main street.
"Adams Express Company."
au 7--ts W. H. Trego, Sup't

div3.head: Hats, Caps and Furs.
div3.p: William. T. Moore & Co.,

The subscribers respectfully announce that they are now in receipt of a large and fine assortment of Hats and Caps, to which they call attention Purchasers would find a rare selection it they examine our stock before buying, as we will offer inducements that cannot fall to please.
We have received a full supply of Ladies' Furs, embracing all the latest styles, which we are selling at the lowest possible price.
Our stock of Servants' Hats and Caps cannot be beat, either in quality or price.
Dress Hats made to order.

Thankful for past favors, they hope for a continuance of the same.
Wm. T. Moore,
M. J. Leonard.
207 Broad street.

div3.head: Fall Trade.1860.
div3.p:
Robert L. Dickinson, (successor to Binford, Dickinson & Weisiger,) No. 78 Main street, Richmond, Va., thankful for the liberal patronage bestowed on him by his friends and the public generally, invites their attention to his large and extensive stock of Hats, Caps, Furs, &c., comprising every style manufactured for the season, which will be sold at wholesale and retail to punctual customers on the most favorable terms.
Merchants of Virginia, North Carolina, and Tennessee, visiting the city, are respectfully solicited to call and examine for themselves before purchasing.
A liberal discount made to those who purchase for cash.

div3.head: Servants' Clothing.
div3.p: --The subscribers for many years have been extensively engaged in manufacturing for factory, field and house servants — Black and Fancy Satinet Suits; Fancy Cassimere Suits; Flushing Over Sacks; Petersham Over Sacks; heavy wool Under Clothing; Hickory and Brown Cotton Shirts.
Suits for boys.--Our assortment comprises everything usually kept for a complete outfit. --Great inducements can be offered to purchasers.
Shafer, Halsey & Co., 110 Main st.
